title: Man's bet turns turns £500 into a £5million pork scratching empire
text:

Not many of us start a business as a bet - but that's how Snaffling Pig began.

Nick Coleman was working on a medical business when his co-founder Udhi Silva bet him he couldn't start a company from scratch with just £500.

And scratch turned out to be an important word - with Nick inspired to base his new venture on something very dear to him.

“I love pork scratchings, I love how they’re one of the few snacks that people get really excited about. They’re also quite divisive and not everyone’s cup of tea,” Nick said.

He's not alone in being a fan though - and within 18 months Snaffling Pig had taken off to the degree that both him and his business partner working on it full time.

It’s now forecast to bring in a whopping £5million this year.

Nick ‒ who now describes himself as the ‘Duke of Pork’ - says that the idea for Snaffling Pig came out of a frustration with the standard of existing pork-based snacks.

In short, he felt the pub favourite was due a makeover.

Suggesting that other producers have stood still with “stale recipes that hadn’t changed for years and see-through packaging”, Nick argued that double-cooking the best parks of the pork rind and seasoning them with exciting flavours he could make people “fall in love with this epic snack again”.

Nick’s mum, a vegetarian, was the first employee - going pub to pub across Essex and Suffolk to try to get people to buy into the products.

“She'd never done sales before, nor eaten meat for 35 years, but she got us listed in over 150 pubs. I owe the success of this brand to her,” Nick said.

Nick admits that the biggest challenge with getting Snaffling Pig off the ground was the simple fact that he didn’t really know how things were supposed to work, from manufacturing to selling to how to deal with orders.

But that didn't stop him trying to find out.

"It’s a steep learning curve and I guess my main skill is that I'm not afraid to look like an idiot. I'm very happy to ask questions and I'm curious how things can be started and improved upon,” Nick explained.

Nick says that spreading the word about Snaffling Pig was a question of “hard graft”.

Once the team had got enough pubs selling them, they could build a case study for how well it was selling against other brands and approach bigger suppliers.

But Nick is clear that nothing has been a more effective sales tool than offering samples.

“The more chance people have of trying our products, the more likely they are to buy it,” he said.

Taking on the Dragons

(Image: BBC Two)

Two years after launch, Nick and his team decided that they needed to boost the funding and awareness of Snaffling Pig. So they went on Dragon’s Den.

Nick admits this was a risk, as not only are the products not for everyone, you can get a rough time from the Dragons.

However, it went well, with the firm attracting a £70,000 investment from Moonpig founder Nick Jenkins.

The firm has since tapped into the crowdfunding market, offering up a 9.73% stake in the business to investors, aiming to raise £750,000.

It was hugely oversubscribed - eventually bringing in more than £1million from almost 1,500 investors.

Snaffling Pig may have started with pork crackling packets, but its growth has meant moving into other products too.

For example, it now has its own beer, which you can get in a gift set alongside a host of the regular pork products, as well as a hot sauce and apple sauce. Pork remains its focus though, from scratching and crackling packs to even an advent calendar.

It’s also now found on the shelves at Tesco and Sainsbury’s, selling flavoured gammon steaks, with plans to launch bacon, sausage and gammon joints, as well as on the go snack bars.

'You don’t need to be rich to succeed'

(Image: Snaffling Pig)

Nick emphasises that would-be entrepreneurs cannot let money ‒ or rather a lack of it ‒ put them off following their dreams.



“If you have an idea, just get out there and start selling it, even if you only have £500.

"You don't need to be clever or rich to start a company, you just need to work hard and figure things out as you go.”
description: Snaffling Pig has sales in the millions and now produces gammon steaks, sauces and even beer - but all began with a bet and man who just really loved pork scratchings
